TEXT.English: [H1]Llywelyn the Great[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Prince of Gwynedd[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD]ca. 1173 - 1240[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Llywelyn Fawr, or Llywelyn the Great, was born in Dolwyddelan Castle in North Wales. Although Llywelyn had many family connections to royalty, it would not offer him any greater chance to gain a position of power. In his early years, Llywelyn's primary enemy would be his uncle, Dafydd. Dafydd had already killed his own brother and seized control of Gwynedd in Northwest Wales by the time Llywelyn was 22. However, Dafydd had made many enemies on his ride to power. Llywelyn led a successful revolution against Dafydd and defeated him in a battle at Aberconwy. Llywelyn was not selfish, and showed early signs of his diplomatic skills by sharing the power of Gwynedd with his cousins. Llywelyn ruled Dafydd's lands east of the Conwy River. [PARAGRAPH:1]In 1200, Llywelyn's cousin Gruffud died. Llywelyn now felt he had sufficient strength to move against Maredudd, his other cousin, and claimed to be the overlord of the whole of North Wales by expelling Maredudd from Llyn and capturing a strategic castle. Llywelyn lead another invasion into Southern Powys, a territory of Gwenwynwyn, another Welsh opponent. [PARAGRAPH:1] By 1205, King John of England recognized the power of the Welsh prince, and offered his daughter Joan in marriage. The alliance resulted in the arrest of Gwenwynwyn, enabling Llywelyn to seize control of his lands. King John eventually realized he had gone too far in his support of Llywelyn. Llywelyn then attacked the lands of the Earl of Chester, and King John was forced to go to war with Llywelyn. The Welsh troops used guerilla tactics and raided the English troop's supplies, leaving King John no choice but to retreat to England. [PARAGRAPH:1]However, King John soon returned to Wales with a larger army. The English army cut right into the heart of Gwynedd, forcing Llywelyn to send his English wife to sue for peace. The terms of the peace were a serious set back for Llywelyn and he lost the right to lands east of the Conwy River. He was also made to forfeit 20,000 cattle and 40 horses to the English. King John made other moves to ensure his defeat of Wales, and the Welsh, under Llywelyn, captured all the English Forts to free themselves of the English. [PARAGRAPH:2]When the English barons began conspiring against King John, he sought the aid of the Welsh. The Welsh gave no support to the king. Llywelyn took the side of the King's enemies, and once more took control of South Wales. An Alliance between the Welsh and the Anglo-Normans make certain that there would be peace on the borders. After King John died, his son King Henry III made a treaty with Llywelyn. Llywelyn knew that maintaining the whole of Wales would be difficult, so put other princes and lords in charge of the various districts, but still retained the position of Overlord. Disputes with the Earl of Pembroke weakened Llywelyn, and only ended when the new Earl of Pembroke formed an alliance with the Welsh. [PARAGRAPH:1]The new treaties kept a peace in Wales until Llywelyn's death in 1240, at the age of 68. He died at Aberconwy Abbey and was interred there.
TEXT.French: [H1]Llywelyn le Grand[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Prince de Gwynedd[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vécu:[\BOLD]ca. 1173 - 1240[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1][BOLD]Fond:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Llywelyn Fawr, ou Llywelyn le Grand, est né en Dolwyddelan Castle dans le nord du pays de Galles. Bien que l'Inde avait de nombreux liens avec la famille royale, il ne serait pas lui offrir plus d'une chance d'acquérir une position de pouvoir. Dans ses premières années, Llywelyn le principal ennemi serait son oncle, Dafydd. Dafydd avait déjà tué son frère et a pris le contrôle de Gwynedd, au nord-ouest du pays de Galles au moment Llywelyn était 22. Toutefois, de nombreux ennemis Dafydd acquise tout au long de ses épreuves. Llywelyn il a réussi un Dafydd révolution contre lui et défait dans une bataille à Aberconwy. Llywelyn n'était pas égoïste, et a montré des signes précoces de ses talents de diplomate en partageant le pouvoir de Gwynedd est avec des cousins. Llywelyn statué Dafydd les terres de l'est de la rivière Conwy. [PARAGRAPH: 1] En l'an 1200, Llywelyn cousin Gruffud décédés. Llywelyn maintenant estimé qu'il avait le pouvoir d'aller contre Maredudd, son autre cousine, et prétend être le maître de l'ensemble du nord du pays de Galles par l'expulsion de Llyn et de la capture stratégique château. Llywelyn entraîner une autre invasion du sud du Powys, un territoire de Gwenwynwyn, un autre adversaire gallois. [PARAGRAPH: 1] En 1205, le roi Jean d'Angleterre a reconnu le pouvoir du prince-évêque gallois, et il a offert sa fille en mariage Joan. L'alliance provoqué l'arrestation de Gwenwynwyn, Llywelyn permettant de s'emparer de ses terres. Le Roi finalement rendu compte qu'il était allé trop loin dans son soutien de Llywelyn. Llywelyn ensuite attaqué les terres de la petite de Chester, et le roi Jean a été forcé d'entrer en guerre avec Llywelyn. Le Welsh troupes utilisé des tactiques de guérilla et a pris les Anglais fournissent la nourriture, John King laissant pas d'autre choix que de retourner en Angleterre. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Toutefois, le Roi John a regagné le Pays de Galles avec une plus grande armée. L'anglais Armée coupe droite dans le coeur de Gwynedd, Llywelyn forcer à envoyer sa femme à négocier pour la paix. Les termes de la paix ont été un grave revers pour le Maroc et il a perdu le droit à des terres est de la rivière Conwy. Il a également été fait pour confisquer 20.000 bovins et 40 chevaux à l'anglais. John King fait d'autres coups de prouver son rachat de baleines, et le gallois, en vertu de Llywelyn, capturé tous les Français Forts de se libérer de l'anglais. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Après l'anglais Barons ont comploté contre le roi Jean, il a demandé l'aide de la Welsh. Le Welsh a donné aucun soutien au roi. Llywelyn a pris le parti de leurs ennemis, et a pris la relève du Sud. Une Alliance entre le gallois et l'Anglo Normands faire certains qu'il n'y aura de paix sur les frontières serait maintenu. Après John King est mort, son fils Henri III fait un traité avec l'Inde. Llywelyn savait que le maintien de l'ensemble du pays de Galles serait difficile, pour mettre les autres Princes et overlords en charge des quartiers, mais en gardant la position de Overlord pour lui-même. Différends avec le comte de Pembroke Llywelyn affaibli, et seulement pris fin lorsque le nouveau début de Pembroke formé une alliance avec le gallois. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Les traités de paix signés conservés au Pays de Galles jusqu'à sa mort, en 1240, à l'âge de 68. Il est décédé à l'abbaye d'Aberconwy et a été enterré.
TEXT.German: [H1]Llywelyn das Große[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Prinz von Gwynedd[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Gelebt:[\BOLD]ca. 1173 1240[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Llywelyn Fawr oder Llywelyn der Große, war geboren in der Dolwyddelan Schloss in North Wales. Obwohl Llywelyn Familie hatte viele Verbindungen zu Lizenzgebühren, wäre es ihm nicht mehr eine Chance, zu einer Position der Macht. In seinen frühen Jahren, in erster Linie Llywelyn Feind würde sein Onkel, Dafydd. Dafydd hatte bereits seinen eigenen Bruder getötet und beschlagnahmt Kontrolle von Gwynedd im Nordwesten von Wales Llywelyn der Zeit wurde 22. Allerdings Dafydd sich viele Feinde in seiner bestehen. Llywelyn führte eine erfolgreiche Revolution gegen Dafydd und besiegt ihn in der Schlacht bei Aberconwy. Llywelyn war nicht egoistisch, und zeigte erste Anzeichen seiner diplomatischen Fähigkeiten durch die Aufteilung der Macht von Gwynedd mit Vettern ist. Dafydd Llywelyn entschieden, die Grundstücke östlich des Conwy River. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Im Jahr 1200, Llywelyn's Cousin Gruffud gestorben. Llywelyn jetzt fühlte er hatte die Macht, sich gegen Maredudd, seine anderen Cousin, und behauptet, dass der Oberherr der gesamten North Wales durch die Ausweisung von ihm Llyn und Aufzeichnung einer strategischen Burg. Llywelyn führen anderen Invasion in Southern Powys, ein Gebiet von Gwenwynwyn, Welsh anderen Gegner. [PARAGRAPH: 1] 1205, König Johann von England anerkannte die Macht des walisischen Prinzen, und bot seine Tochter Joan in der Ehe. Die Allianz führte zur Festnahme von Gwenwynwyn, damit Llywelyn zu ergreifen, die Kontrolle über seine Grundstücke. Der König schließlich realisierte er zu weit gegangen in seiner Unterstützung von Llywelyn. Llywelyn dann angegriffen dem Boden in der Frühe von Chester, und König John war gezwungen, in den Krieg mit Llywelyn. Die walisische Truppen verwendet Guerilla-Taktik und nahm die englische Truppenstärke der Nahrung, so dass King John keine andere Wahl, als die Rückkehr nach England. [PARAGRAPH: 1] jedoch, King John zurück nach Wales mit einer größeren Armee. Die englische Armee Schnitt rechts in die Herzen von Gwynedd, Llywelyn zwingen zu senden seiner Frau für den Frieden zu verhandeln. Die Bedingungen des Friedens waren eine schwere Rückschlag für Llywelyn und verlor er das Recht auf Land östlich des Flusses Conwy. Er wurde auch zu verfallen 20.000 Rinder und 40 Pferde, die Englisch. King John aus anderen zieht um seine übernahme der Wale, und der Welsh, unter Llywelyn, gefangen aller englischen Forts, die sich der englischen. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Nach der englischen Barons wurden Verschwörung gegen König John, suchte er die Hilfe der Waliser. Der Waliser hat keine Unterstützung für den König. Llywelyn nahm der Seite der Feinde, und übernahm South Wales. Eine Allianz zwischen dem Waliser und der Anglo Normannen stellen sicher, dass es den Frieden auf die Grenzen würde beibehalten werden. Nach King John starb, wurde sein Sohn König Heinrich III, die einen Vertrag mit Llywelyn. Llywelyn wusste, dass die Aufrechterhaltung der gesamten Wales wäre schwierig, so dass die anderen Fürsten und Herren in der Stadtteile, aber noch halten die Position von Overlord für sich. Streitigkeiten mit den Earl of Pembroke Llywelyn geschwächt, und erst beendet, wenn der neue Early von Pembroke ein Bündnis mit der walisischen. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Die Verträge unterzeichnet haben eine Frieden in Wales bis zu seinem Tod im Jahre 1240, im Alter von 68. Er starb in der Abtei von Aberconwy und wurde dort begraben.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Llywelyn il Grande[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Principe di Gwynedd[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivo:[\BOLD]c.1173 - 1240[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1][BOLD]Priorità bassa:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Llywelyn Fawr, o Llywelyn il Grande, è nato in Dolwyddelan Castle nel nord del Galles. Sebbene Llywelyn avuto molti collegamenti con la famiglia di royalties, che non offrono alcun lui pi� di una possibilità di conquistare una posizione di potere. Nei suoi primi anni, il principale nemico Llywelyn sarebbe suo zio, Dafydd. Dafydd aveva già ucciso suo fratello e il controllo di Gwynedd sequestrate nel Galles nordoccidentale, al momento Llywelyn è stato 22. Tuttavia, Dafydd guadagnato molti nemici per tutta la sua prove. Llywelyn ha portato con successo contro la rivoluzione Dafydd e lo sconfitto in una battaglia a Aberconwy. Llywelyn non era egoista, e ha mostrato i primi segnali della sua abilità diplomatica per la condivisione del potere con Gwynedd è cugini. Llywelyn statuito Dafydd di terre ad est del fiume Conwy. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Nel 1200, Llywelyn cugino Gruffud morto. Llywelyn ora aveva sentito il potere di spostare Maredudd contro, il suo altro cugino, e sosteneva di essere il overlord di tutto il nord del Galles da espellere da lui Llyn e strategica acquisizione di un castello. Llywelyn condurre un'altra invasione in Powys Meridionale, un territorio di Gwenwynwyn, un altro gallese avversario. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Per 1205, re d'Inghilterra Giovanni riconosciuto il potere del principe del Galles, e ha offerto la sua figlia Joan nel matrimonio. L'alleanza ha causato l'arresto di Gwenwynwyn, Llywelyn consentendo di riprendere il controllo delle sue terre. Il Re eventualmente realizzato era andato troppo in là nel suo sostegno di Llywelyn. Llywelyn poi attaccato le terre dei primi di Chester, e King John, che è stato costretto a scendere in guerra con Llywelyn. Il gallese truppe usato tattiche di guerriglia e ha preso l'inglese truppe del cibo, lasciando Re Giovanni scelta, ma non per tornare in Inghilterra. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Tuttavia, Re Giovanni ritornò in Galles con un maggiore esercito. L'esercito inglese tagliare nel cuore di Gwynedd, costringendo Llywelyn per inviare la moglie a negoziare per la pace. I termini dell'accordo di pace sono stati un grave arretrato per Llywelyn e ha perso il diritto di terre ad est del fiume Conwy. E 'stato anche fatto incamerata 20.000 bovini e 40 cavalli per la lingua inglese. Re Giovanni fatto altre mosse per provare la sua acquisizione di balene, e il gallese, sotto Llywelyn, catturato tutti gli inglesi forti di liberarsi della lingua inglese. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Dopo gli inglesi sono stati Baroni complottare contro il re Giovanni, che egli ha sempre cercato l'aiuto del gallese. Il gallese ha dato alcun sostegno per il re. Llywelyn ha preso il lato dei nemici, e ha assunto Galles del Sud. Un'Alleanza tra i gallesi e la Anglo Normanni rendere certo che ci sarebbe la pace alle frontiere sarebbe mantenuto. Dopo il Re Giovanni morì, suo figlio Enrico III fatto un trattato con Llywelyn. Llywelyn sapeva che il mantenimento di tutto il Galles sarebbe difficile, in modo da mettere in altri Principi e padroni responsabili dei quartieri, ma sempre mantenendo la posizione di Overlord per se stesso. Controversie con il Conte di Pembroke Llywelyn indebolita, e si è conclusa solo quando il nuovo formato di Pembroke Early un'alleanza con il gallese. [PARAGRAPH: 1] I trattati di pace firmati conservati in Galles, fino alla sua morte nel 1240, all'età di 68. Morì a abbazia di Aberconwy e fu sepolto.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Llywelyn el Grande[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Príncipe de Gwynedd[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivido:[\BOLD]c.1173 - 1240[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1][BOLD]Fondo:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Llywelyn Fawr, o Llywelyn el Grande, nació en Dolwyddelan Castle en el norte de Gales. Aunque Llywelyn había muchas conexiones con la familia de regalías, que no le ofrecen más de una oportunidad para obtener una posición de poder. En sus primeros años, Llywelyn principal del enemigo sería su tío, Dafydd. Dafydd ya habían asesinado a su propio hermano y tomado el control de Gwynedd en el noroeste de Gales por el momento Llywelyn fue 22. Sin embargo, Dafydd ganado muchos enemigos en todo su pruebas. Llywelyn encabezó una exitosa revolución contra Dafydd y le derrotó en una batalla en Aberconwy. Llywelyn no era egoísta, y mostró los primeros indicios de su capacidad diplomática por compartir el poder de Gwynedd es con primos. Llywelyn dictaminó Dafydd tierras del este del río Conwy. [PARAGRAPH: 1] En el año 1200, Llywelyn del primo Gruffud murió. Llywelyn ahora sentía que él tenía el poder de mover contra Maredudd, su otro primo, y se ha afirmado que a evitar la de todo el Norte de Gales por expulsión de Llyn y estratégico de la captura de un castillo. Llywelyn conducir otra invasión en el sur de Powys, un territorio de Gwenwynwyn, otro galés oponente. [PARAGRAPH: 1] En 1205, el rey Juan de Inglaterra reconoció el poder del príncipe de Gales, y ofreció a su hija Joan en el matrimonio. La alianza provocó la detención de Gwenwynwyn, lo que permite Llywelyn a tomar el control de sus tierras. El Rey cuenta de que el tiempo había ido demasiado lejos en su apoyo de Llywelyn. Llywelyn luego atacaron las tierras de los Temprana de Chester, y el Rey Juan se vio obligado a ir a la guerra con Llywelyn. El galés tropas utilizan tácticas de guerrilla y la toma de alimentos que aportan Inglés, dejando a King John no tiene más opción que regresar a Inglaterra. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Sin embargo, el Rey Juan regresó a Gales con un mayor del ejército. El corte Inglés Ejército de la derecha en el corazón de Gwynedd, lo que obligó a Llywelyn enviar a su esposa a negociar por la paz. Las condiciones de la paz son un serio retroceso para Llywelyn y perdió el derecho a las tierras al este del río Conwy. También fue obligado a renunciar a 20.000 bovinos y 40 caballos al Inglés. King John hecho otros movimientos para probar su toma de Ballenas, y la galesa, en virtud de Llywelyn, a todos los capturados Inglés Forts a liberarse del Inglés. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Después de la Barons Inglés estaban tramando en contra de John King, buscó la ayuda de los galeses. El galés negaron su apoyo al rey. Llywelyn tomó el lado de los enemigos, y se hizo cargo de Gales del Sur. Una alianza entre el galés y el Anglo normandos asegurarse de que no habría paz en las fronteras se mantendrían. Después de King John murió, su hijo el rey Enrique III hizo un tratado con Llywelyn. Llywelyn sabía que el mantenimiento de la totalidad de Gales sería difícil, de modo que los demás príncipes feudales y encargado de los barrios, pero aún se mantiene la posición de Overlord para sí mismo. Controversias con el conde de Pembroke debilitado Llywelyn, y sólo terminó cuando el nuevo temprana de Pembroke formado una alianza con los galeses. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Los tratados firmados mantenido una paz en el País de Gales hasta su muerte en 1240, a la edad de 68. Murió en la abadía de Aberconwy y fue enterrado allí.

TEXT.English: [CT_NAME], you are as welcome a sight in these lands as a Viking slave-hunter. If you mind your manners well enough, we may treat you better.

TEXT.English: [H1]Canute the Great[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of England, Denmark, and Norway[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD]ca. 985 - 1035 [NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Cnut the Great, more commonly known as Canute, was a king of Denmark, England, Norway, and parts of Sweden, together often referred to as the Anglo-Scandinavian or North Sea Empire. After the death of his heirs within a decade of his own and the Norman conquest of England in 1066, his legacy was largely lost to history. Historian Norman Cantor has made the statement that he was "the most effective king in Anglo-Saxon history", despite his not being Anglo-Saxon. [PARAGRAPH:1]Cnut was of Danish and Slavic descent. His father was Sweyn Forkbeard, King of Denmark (which gave Cnut the patronym Sweynsson, Old Norse Sveinsson). Cnut's mother was the daughter of the first duke of the Polans, Mieszko I; her name may have been Swietoslawa, but the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography article on Cnut (published 2004) states that her name is unknown. [PARAGRAPH:1]As a prince of Denmark, Cnut won the throne of England in 1016 in the wake of centuries of Viking activity in northwestern Europe. His accession to the Danish throne in 1018 brought the crowns of England and Denmark together. Cnut maintained his power by uniting Danes and Englishmen under cultural bonds of wealth and custom, rather than by sheer brutality. After a decade of conflict with opponents in Scandinavia, Cnut claimed the crown of Norway in Trondheim in 1028. The Swedish city Sigtuna was held by Cnut. He had coins struck there that called him king, but there is no narrative record of his occupation. [PARAGRAPH:1]The kingship of England lent the Danes an important link to the maritime zone between the islands of Great Britain and Ireland, where Cnut, like his father before him, had a strong interest and wielded much influence among the Gall-Ghaedhil, the Norse-Gaels, a people who dominated much of the Irish Sea region, including the Isle of Man, and western Scotland for a part of the Middle Ages; they were of Gaelic and North Germanic origin and as a whole exhibited a great deal of Gaelic and Norse cultural syncretism. [PARAGRAPH:1]Cnut's possession of England's dioceses and the continental Diocese of Denmark - with a claim laid upon it by the Holy Roman Empire's Archdiocese of Hamburg-Bremen - was a source of great leverage within the Church, gaining notable concessions from Pope Benedict VIII and his successor John XIX, such as one on the price of the pallium of his bishops. A pallium is an ecclesiastical vestment that was originally peculiar to the Pope, but for many centuries bestowed by him on metropolitans and primates as a symbol of the jurisdiction delegated to them by the Holy See. In that context it has remained connected to the papacy. At the time of this concession, Cnut was able provide his bishops with pallia equal in value and ostentation to those worn by the Pope himself, a not insignificant matter. During the coronation of the Holy Roman Emperor, Cnut also gained concessions on the tolls his people had to pay on the way to Rome from other magnates of medieval Christendom. After his 1026 victory against Norway and Sweden, and on his way to Rome for this coronation, Cnut, in a letter written for the benefit of his subjects, stated himself to be "king of all England and Denmark and the Norwegians and of some of the Swedes". Not an idle boast. At the time, he was more powerful and wealthier than the Holy Roman Emperor. [PARAGRAPH:2]Cnut ruled England for almost twenty years. The protection he lent against Viking raiders - many of them under his command - restored the prosperity that had been increasingly impaired since the resumption of Viking attacks in the 980s. The resources he commanded in England helped him to establish control of the majority of Scandinavia, too. [PARAGRAPH:1]In July 1017, to consolidate his power, Cnut wed Emma of Normandy, the widow of Æthelred and daughter of Richard the Fearless, the first Duke of Normandy. With Edmund dead, Cnut was quick to eliminate any prospective challenge from the survivors of the Wessex dynasty. The first year of his reign was marked by the executions of a number of English noblemen whom he considered suspect. Æthelred's son Eadwig fled from England but was killed on Cnut's orders. Edmund Ironside's sons Edward and Edmund likewise fled abroad, Edward eventually to Hungary. Emma's sons by Æthelred, Edward the Confessor and Alfred Atheling, went into exile among their relatives in Normandy. Cnut put forward Harthacnut, his son by Emma, to be his heir; Svein Knutsson and Harold Harefoot, his two sons from his marriage to Ælfgifu of Northampton, his handfast wife, were kept on the sidelines. [PARAGRAPH:1]In 1018, having collected a Danegeld amounting to the colossal sum of £72,000 levied nationwide, with an additional £10,500 extracted from London, Cnut paid off his army and sent most of them home. He retained 40 ships and their crews as a standing force in England. An annual tax called heregeld (army payment) was collected through the same system Æthelred had instituted in 1012 to reward Scandinavians in his service. [PARAGRAPH:1]Cnut extended the existing trend for multiple shires to be grouped together under a single ealdorman, dividing the country into four large administrative units whose geographical extent was based on the largest and most durable of the separate kingdoms that had preceded the unification of England. The officials responsible for these provinces were designated earls, a title of Scandinavian origin already in localised use in England, which now everywhere replaced that of ealdorman. Wessex was initially kept under Cnut's personal control, while Northumbria went to Erik of Hlathir, East Anglia to Thorkell the Tall, and Mercia remained in the hands of Eadric Streona. [PARAGRAPH:1]This initial distribution of power was short-lived. The chronically treacherous Eadric was executed within a year of Cnut's accession. Mercia passed to one of the leading families of the region, probably first to Leofwine, ealdorman of the Hwicce under Æthelred, but certainly soon to his son Leofric. In 1021 Thorkel the Tall also fell from favour and was outlawed. Following the death of Erik in the 1020s, he was succeeded as Earl of Northumbria by Siward, whose grandmother, Estrid (married to Úlfr Thorgilsson--a Viking chieftain and one of Cnut's most trusted men), was Cnut's sister. Bernicia, the northern part of Northumbria, was theoretically part of Erik and Siward's earldom, but throughout Cnut's reign it effectively remained under the control of the English dynasty based at Bamburgh, which had dominated the area at least since the early 10th century. They served as junior Earls of Bernicia under the titular authority of the Earl of Northumbria. By the 1030s Cnut's direct administration of Wessex had come to an end, with the establishment of an earldom under Godwin, an Englishman from a powerful Sussex family. In general, after initial reliance on his Scandinavian followers in the first years of his reign, Cnut allowed those Anglo-Saxon families of the existing English nobility who had earned his trust to assume rulership of his Earldoms. [PARAGRAPH:2]But by concentrating his efforts to secure control of England, Cnut's authority waned in Denmark and Norway. At the Battle of Nesjar, in 1016, Olaf Haraldsson won the kingdom of Norway from the Danes. It was at some time after Eirkr left for England, and on the death of Svein while retreating to Sweden, maybe intent on returning to Norway with reinforcements, that Erikr's son Hakon went to join his father and support Cnut in England, too. [PARAGRAPH:1]Cnut's brother Harald may have been at Cnut's coronation, in 1016, returning to Denmark as its king, with part of the fleet, at some point thereafter. It is only certain, though, that there was an entry of his name, alongside Cnut's, in confraternity with Christ Church, Canterbury, in 1018. This is not conclusive, though, for the entry may have been made in Harald's absence, perhaps by the hand of Cnut himself, which means that, while it is usually thought that Harald died in 1018, it is unsure whether he was still alive at this point. Entry of his brother's name in the Canterbury codex may have been Cnut's attempt to make his vengeance for Harald's murder good with the Church. Of course, this may have been just a gesture for a soul to be under the protection of God. There is evidence Cnut was in battle with pirates in 1018, with his destruction of the crews of thirty ships, although it is unknown if this was off the English or Danish shores. He himself mentions troubles in his 1019 letter (to England, from Denmark), written as the King of England and Denmark. These events can be seen, with plausibility, to be in connection with the death of Harald. Cnut says he dealt with dissenters to ensure Denmark was free to assist England: [PARAGRAPH:2]"King Cnut greets in friendship his archbishop and his diocesan bishops and Earl Thurkil and all his earls... ecclesiatic and lay, in England... I inform you that I will be a gracious lord and a faithfull observer of God's rights and just secular law. (He exhorts his ealdormen to assist the bishops in the maintenance of) God's rights... and the benefit of the people. [PARAGRAPH:1]"If anyone, ecclesiastic or layman, Dane or Englishman, is so presumptuous as to defy God's law and my royal authority or the secular laws, and he will not make amends and desist according to the direction of my bishops, I then pray, and also command, Earl Thurkil, if he can, to cause the evil-doer to do right. And if he cannot, then it is my will that with the power of us both he shall destroy him in the land or drive him out of the land, whether he be of high or low rank. And it is my will that all the nation, ecclesiatical and lay, shall steadfastly observe Edgar's laws, which all men have chosen and sworn at Oxford. [PARAGRAPH:1]"Since I did not spare my money, as long as hostility was threatening you, I with God's help have put an end to it. Then I was informed that greater danger was approaching us than we liked at all; and then I went myself with the men who accompanied me to Denmark, from where the greatest injury had come to us, and with God's help I have made it so that never henceforth shall hostility reach you from there as long as you support me rightly and my life lasts. Now I thank Almighty God for his help and his mercy, that I have settled the great dangers which were approaching us that we need fear no danger to us from there; but we may rekon on full help and deliverance, if we need it" [NEWLINE]--Cnut's letter of 1019 [PARAGRAPH:2]Cnut was generally remembered as a wise and successful king of England, although this view may in part be attributable to his good treatment of the Church, keeper of the historic record. Accordingly, we hear of him, even today, as a religious man (see below), despite the fact that he was in an arguably sinful relationship, with two wives, and the harsh treatment he dealt his fellow Christian opponents. [PARAGRAPH:1]Under his reign, Cnut brought together the English and Danish kingdoms, and the people saw a golden age of dominance across Scandinavia, as well as within the British Isles. His campaigns abroad meant the tables of Viking supremacy were stacked in favour of the English, turning the prows of the longships towards Scandinavia. He reinstated the Laws of King Edgar to allow for the constitution of a Danelaw, and for the activity of Scandinavians at large. He also reinstituted the extant laws with a series of proclamations to assuage common grievances brought to his attention, including: "On Inheritance in case of Intestacy", and "On Heriots and Reliefs". He also strengthened the currency, initiating a reform of coins so that those in use in England were of equal weight to those being used in Denmark and other parts of Scandinavia, and thus English coinage came to be accepted for purchases by traders as far away as Constantinople and Damascus.
TEXT.French: [H1]Cnut le Grand[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of England, Denmark, and Norway[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD]ca. 985 - 1035 [NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Cnut the Great, more commonly known as Canute, was a king of Denmark, England, Norway, and parts of Sweden, together often referred to as the Anglo-Scandinavian or North Sea Empire. After the death of his heirs within a decade of his own and the Norman conquest of England in 1066, his legacy was largely lost to history. Historian Norman Cantor has made the statement that he was "the most effective king in Anglo-Saxon history", despite his not being Anglo-Saxon. [PARAGRAPH:1]Cnut was of Danish and Slavic descent. His father was Sweyn Forkbeard, King of Denmark (which gave Cnut the patronym Sweynsson, Old Norse Sveinsson). Cnut's mother was the daughter of the first duke of the Polans, Mieszko I; her name may have been Swietoslawa, but the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography article on Cnut (published 2004) states that her name is unknown. [PARAGRAPH:1]As a prince of Denmark, Cnut won the throne of England in 1016 in the wake of centuries of Viking activity in northwestern Europe. His accession to the Danish throne in 1018 brought the crowns of England and Denmark together. Cnut maintained his power by uniting Danes and Englishmen under cultural bonds of wealth and custom, rather than by sheer brutality. After a decade of conflict with opponents in Scandinavia, Cnut claimed the crown of Norway in Trondheim in 1028. The Swedish city Sigtuna was held by Cnut. He had coins struck there that called him king, but there is no narrative record of his occupation. [PARAGRAPH:1]The kingship of England lent the Danes an important link to the maritime zone between the islands of Great Britain and Ireland, where Cnut, like his father before him, had a strong interest and wielded much influence among the Gall-Ghaedhil, the Norse-Gaels, a people who dominated much of the Irish Sea region, including the Isle of Man, and western Scotland for a part of the Middle Ages; they were of Gaelic and North Germanic origin and as a whole exhibited a great deal of Gaelic and Norse cultural syncretism. [PARAGRAPH:1]Cnut's possession of England's dioceses and the continental Diocese of Denmark - with a claim laid upon it by the Holy Roman Empire's Archdiocese of Hamburg-Bremen - was a source of great leverage within the Church, gaining notable concessions from Pope Benedict VIII and his successor John XIX, such as one on the price of the pallium of his bishops. A pallium is an ecclesiastical vestment that was originally peculiar to the Pope, but for many centuries bestowed by him on metropolitans and primates as a symbol of the jurisdiction delegated to them by the Holy See. In that context it has remained connected to the papacy. At the time of this concession, Cnut was able provide his bishops with pallia equal in value and ostentation to those worn by the Pope himself, a not insignificant matter. During the coronation of the Holy Roman Emperor, Cnut also gained concessions on the tolls his people had to pay on the way to Rome from other magnates of medieval Christendom. After his 1026 victory against Norway and Sweden, and on his way to Rome for this coronation, Cnut, in a letter written for the benefit of his subjects, stated himself to be "king of all England and Denmark and the Norwegians and of some of the Swedes". Not an idle boast. At the time, he was more powerful and wealthier than the Holy Roman Emperor. [PARAGRAPH:2]Cnut ruled England for almost twenty years. The protection he lent against Viking raiders - many of them under his command - restored the prosperity that had been increasingly impaired since the resumption of Viking attacks in the 980s. The resources he commanded in England helped him to establish control of the majority of Scandinavia, too. [PARAGRAPH:1]In July 1017, to consolidate his power, Cnut wed Emma of Normandy, the widow of Æthelred and daughter of Richard the Fearless, the first Duke of Normandy. With Edmund dead, Cnut was quick to eliminate any prospective challenge from the survivors of the Wessex dynasty. The first year of his reign was marked by the executions of a number of English noblemen whom he considered suspect. Æthelred's son Eadwig fled from England but was killed on Cnut's orders. Edmund Ironside's sons Edward and Edmund likewise fled abroad, Edward eventually to Hungary. Emma's sons by Æthelred, Edward the Confessor and Alfred Atheling, went into exile among their relatives in Normandy. Cnut put forward Harthacnut, his son by Emma, to be his heir; Svein Knutsson and Harold Harefoot, his two sons from his marriage to Ælfgifu of Northampton, his handfast wife, were kept on the sidelines. [PARAGRAPH:1]In 1018, having collected a Danegeld amounting to the colossal sum of £72,000 levied nationwide, with an additional £10,500 extracted from London, Cnut paid off his army and sent most of them home. He retained 40 ships and their crews as a standing force in England. An annual tax called heregeld (army payment) was collected through the same system Æthelred had instituted in 1012 to reward Scandinavians in his service. [PARAGRAPH:1]Cnut extended the existing trend for multiple shires to be grouped together under a single ealdorman, dividing the country into four large administrative units whose geographical extent was based on the largest and most durable of the separate kingdoms that had preceded the unification of England. The officials responsible for these provinces were designated earls, a title of Scandinavian origin already in localised use in England, which now everywhere replaced that of ealdorman. Wessex was initially kept under Cnut's personal control, while Northumbria went to Erik of Hlathir, East Anglia to Thorkell the Tall, and Mercia remained in the hands of Eadric Streona. [PARAGRAPH:1]This initial distribution of power was short-lived. The chronically treacherous Eadric was executed within a year of Cnut's accession. Mercia passed to one of the leading families of the region, probably first to Leofwine, ealdorman of the Hwicce under Æthelred, but certainly soon to his son Leofric. In 1021 Thorkel the Tall also fell from favour and was outlawed. Following the death of Erik in the 1020s, he was succeeded as Earl of Northumbria by Siward, whose grandmother, Estrid (married to Úlfr Thorgilsson--a Viking chieftain and one of Cnut's most trusted men), was Cnut's sister. Bernicia, the northern part of Northumbria, was theoretically part of Erik and Siward's earldom, but throughout Cnut's reign it effectively remained under the control of the English dynasty based at Bamburgh, which had dominated the area at least since the early 10th century. They served as junior Earls of Bernicia under the titular authority of the Earl of Northumbria. By the 1030s Cnut's direct administration of Wessex had come to an end, with the establishment of an earldom under Godwin, an Englishman from a powerful Sussex family. In general, after initial reliance on his Scandinavian followers in the first years of his reign, Cnut allowed those Anglo-Saxon families of the existing English nobility who had earned his trust to assume rulership of his Earldoms. [PARAGRAPH:2]But by concentrating his efforts to secure control of England, Cnut's authority waned in Denmark and Norway. At the Battle of Nesjar, in 1016, Olaf Haraldsson won the kingdom of Norway from the Danes. It was at some time after Eirkr left for England, and on the death of Svein while retreating to Sweden, maybe intent on returning to Norway with reinforcements, that Erikr's son Hakon went to join his father and support Cnut in England, too. [PARAGRAPH:1]Cnut's brother Harald may have been at Cnut's coronation, in 1016, returning to Denmark as its king, with part of the fleet, at some point thereafter. It is only certain, though, that there was an entry of his name, alongside Cnut's, in confraternity with Christ Church, Canterbury, in 1018. This is not conclusive, though, for the entry may have been made in Harald's absence, perhaps by the hand of Cnut himself, which means that, while it is usually thought that Harald died in 1018, it is unsure whether he was still alive at this point. Entry of his brother's name in the Canterbury codex may have been Cnut's attempt to make his vengeance for Harald's murder good with the Church. Of course, this may have been just a gesture for a soul to be under the protection of God. There is evidence Cnut was in battle with pirates in 1018, with his destruction of the crews of thirty ships, although it is unknown if this was off the English or Danish shores. He himself mentions troubles in his 1019 letter (to England, from Denmark), written as the King of England and Denmark. These events can be seen, with plausibility, to be in connection with the death of Harald. Cnut says he dealt with dissenters to ensure Denmark was free to assist England: [PARAGRAPH:2]"King Cnut greets in friendship his archbishop and his diocesan bishops and Earl Thurkil and all his earls... ecclesiatic and lay, in England... I inform you that I will be a gracious lord and a faithfull observer of God's rights and just secular law. (He exhorts his ealdormen to assist the bishops in the maintenance of) God's rights... and the benefit of the people. [PARAGRAPH:1]"If anyone, ecclesiastic or layman, Dane or Englishman, is so presumptuous as to defy God's law and my royal authority or the secular laws, and he will not make amends and desist according to the direction of my bishops, I then pray, and also command, Earl Thurkil, if he can, to cause the evil-doer to do right. And if he cannot, then it is my will that with the power of us both he shall destroy him in the land or drive him out of the land, whether he be of high or low rank. And it is my will that all the nation, ecclesiatical and lay, shall steadfastly observe Edgar's laws, which all men have chosen and sworn at Oxford. [PARAGRAPH:1]"Since I did not spare my money, as long as hostility was threatening you, I with God's help have put an end to it. Then I was informed that greater danger was approaching us than we liked at all; and then I went myself with the men who accompanied me to Denmark, from where the greatest injury had come to us, and with God's help I have made it so that never henceforth shall hostility reach you from there as long as you support me rightly and my life lasts. Now I thank Almighty God for his help and his mercy, that I have settled the great dangers which were approaching us that we need fear no danger to us from there; but we may rekon on full help and deliverance, if we need it" [NEWLINE]--Cnut's letter of 1019 [PARAGRAPH:2]Cnut was generally remembered as a wise and successful king of England, although this view may in part be attributable to his good treatment of the Church, keeper of the historic record. Accordingly, we hear of him, even today, as a religious man (see below), despite the fact that he was in an arguably sinful relationship, with two wives, and the harsh treatment he dealt his fellow Christian opponents. [PARAGRAPH:1]Under his reign, Cnut brought together the English and Danish kingdoms, and the people saw a golden age of dominance across Scandinavia, as well as within the British Isles. His campaigns abroad meant the tables of Viking supremacy were stacked in favour of the English, turning the prows of the longships towards Scandinavia. He reinstated the Laws of King Edgar to allow for the constitution of a Danelaw, and for the activity of Scandinavians at large. He also reinstituted the extant laws with a series of proclamations to assuage common grievances brought to his attention, including: "On Inheritance in case of Intestacy", and "On Heriots and Reliefs". He also strengthened the currency, initiating a reform of coins so that those in use in England were of equal weight to those being used in Denmark and other parts of Scandinavia, and thus English coinage came to be accepted for purchases by traders as far away as Constantinople and Damascus.

The first year of his reign was marked by the executions of a number of English noblemen whom he considered suspect. Æthelred's son Eadwig fled from England but was killed on Cnut's orders. Edmund Ironside's sons Edward and Edmund likewise fled abroad, Edward eventually to Hungary. Emma's sons by Æthelred, Edward the Confessor and Alfred Atheling, went into exile among their relatives in Normandy. Cnut put forward Harthacnut, his son by Emma, to be his heir; Svein Knutsson and Harold Harefoot, his two sons from his marriage to Ælfgifu of Northampton, his handfast wife, were kept on the sidelines. [PARAGRAPH:1]In 1018, having collected a Danegeld amounting to the colossal sum of £72,000 levied nationwide, with an additional £10,500 extracted from London, Cnut paid off his army and sent most of them home. He retained 40 ships and their crews as a standing force in England. An annual tax called heregeld (army payment) was collected through the same system Æthelred had instituted in 1012 to reward Scandinavians in his service. [PARAGRAPH:1]Cnut extended the existing trend for multiple shires to be grouped together under a single ealdorman, dividing the country into four large administrative units whose geographical extent was based on the largest and most durable of the separate kingdoms that had preceded the unification of England. The officials responsible for these provinces were designated earls, a title of Scandinavian origin already in localised use in England, which now everywhere replaced that of ealdorman. Wessex was initially kept under Cnut's personal control, while Northumbria went to Erik of Hlathir, East Anglia to Thorkell the Tall, and Mercia remained in the hands of Eadric Streona. [PARAGRAPH:1]This initial distribution of power was short-lived. The chronically treacherous Eadric was executed within a year of Cnut's accession. Mercia passed to one of the leading families of the region, probably first to Leofwine, ealdorman of the Hwicce under Æthelred, but certainly soon to his son Leofric. In 1021 Thorkel the Tall also fell from favour and was outlawed. Following the death of Erik in the 1020s, he was succeeded as Earl of Northumbria by Siward, whose grandmother, Estrid (married to Úlfr Thorgilsson--a Viking chieftain and one of Cnut's most trusted men), was Cnut's sister. Bernicia, the northern part of Northumbria, was theoretically part of Erik and Siward's earldom, but throughout Cnut's reign it effectively remained under the control of the English dynasty based at Bamburgh, which had dominated the area at least since the early 10th century. They served as junior Earls of Bernicia under the titular authority of the Earl of Northumbria. By the 1030s Cnut's direct administration of Wessex had come to an end, with the establishment of an earldom under Godwin, an Englishman from a powerful Sussex family. In general, after initial reliance on his Scandinavian followers in the first years of his reign, Cnut allowed those Anglo-Saxon families of the existing English nobility who had earned his trust to assume rulership of his Earldoms. [PARAGRAPH:2]But by concentrating his efforts to secure control of England, Cnut's authority waned in Denmark and Norway. At the Battle of Nesjar, in 1016, Olaf Haraldsson won the kingdom of Norway from the Danes. It was at some time after Eirkr left for England, and on the death of Svein while retreating to Sweden, maybe intent on returning to Norway with reinforcements, that Erikr's son Hakon went to join his father and support Cnut in England, too. [PARAGRAPH:1]Cnut's brother Harald may have been at Cnut's coronation, in 1016, returning to Denmark as its king, with part of the fleet, at some point thereafter. It is only certain, though, that there was an entry of his name, alongside Cnut's, in confraternity with Christ Church, Canterbury, in 1018. This is not conclusive, though, for the entry may have been made in Harald's absence, perhaps by the hand of Cnut himself, which means that, while it is usually thought that Harald died in 1018, it is unsure whether he was still alive at this point. Entry of his brother's name in the Canterbury codex may have been Cnut's attempt to make his vengeance for Harald's murder good with the Church. Of course, this may have been just a gesture for a soul to be under the protection of God. There is evidence Cnut was in battle with pirates in 1018, with his destruction of the crews of thirty ships, although it is unknown if this was off the English or Danish shores. He himself mentions troubles in his 1019 letter (to England, from Denmark), written as the King of England and Denmark. These events can be seen, with plausibility, to be in connection with the death of Harald. Cnut says he dealt with dissenters to ensure Denmark was free to assist England: [PARAGRAPH:2]"King Cnut greets in friendship his archbishop and his diocesan bishops and Earl Thurkil and all his earls... ecclesiatic and lay, in England... I inform you that I will be a gracious lord and a faithfull observer of God's rights and just secular law. (He exhorts his ealdormen to assist the bishops in the maintenance of) God's rights... and the benefit of the people. [PARAGRAPH:1]"If anyone, ecclesiastic or layman, Dane or Englishman, is so presumptuous as to defy God's law and my royal authority or the secular laws, and he will not make amends and desist according to the direction of my bishops, I then pray, and also command, Earl Thurkil, if he can, to cause the evil-doer to do right. And if he cannot, then it is my will that with the power of us both he shall destroy him in the land or drive him out of the land, whether he be of high or low rank. And it is my will that all the nation, ecclesiatical and lay, shall steadfastly observe Edgar's laws, which all men have chosen and sworn at Oxford. [PARAGRAPH:1]"Since I did not spare my money, as long as hostility was threatening you, I with God's help have put an end to it. Then I was informed that greater danger was approaching us than we liked at all; and then I went myself with the men who accompanied me to Denmark, from where the greatest injury had come to us, and with God's help I have made it so that never henceforth shall hostility reach you from there as long as you support me rightly and my life lasts. Now I thank Almighty God for his help and his mercy, that I have settled the great dangers which were approaching us that we need fear no danger to us from there; but we may rekon on full help and deliverance, if we need it" [NEWLINE]--Cnut's letter of 1019 [PARAGRAPH:2]Cnut was generally remembered as a wise and successful king of England, although this view may in part be attributable to his good treatment of the Church, keeper of the historic record. Accordingly, we hear of him, even today, as a religious man (see below), despite the fact that he was in an arguably sinful relationship, with two wives, and the harsh treatment he dealt his fellow Christian opponents. [PARAGRAPH:1]Under his reign, Cnut brought together the English and Danish kingdoms, and the people saw a golden age of dominance across Scandinavia, as well as within the British Isles. His campaigns abroad meant the tables of Viking supremacy were stacked in favour of the English, turning the prows of the longships towards Scandinavia. He reinstated the Laws of King Edgar to allow for the constitution of a Danelaw, and for the activity of Scandinavians at large. He also reinstituted the extant laws with a series of proclamations to assuage common grievances brought to his attention, including: "On Inheritance in case of Intestacy", and "On Heriots and Reliefs". He also strengthened the currency, initiating a reform of coins so that those in use in England were of equal weight to those being used in Denmark and other parts of Scandinavia, and thus English coinage came to be accepted for purchases by traders as far away as Constantinople and Damascus.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Canuto el Grande[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of England, Denmark, and Norway[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD]ca. 985 - 1035 [NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Cnut the Great, more commonly known as Canute, was a king of Denmark, England, Norway, and parts of Sweden, together often referred to as the Anglo-Scandinavian or North Sea Empire. After the death of his heirs within a decade of his own and the Norman conquest of England in 1066, his legacy was largely lost to history. Historian Norman Cantor has made the statement that he was "the most effective king in Anglo-Saxon history", despite his not being Anglo-Saxon. [PARAGRAPH:1]Cnut was of Danish and Slavic descent. His father was Sweyn Forkbeard, King of Denmark (which gave Cnut the patronym Sweynsson, Old Norse Sveinsson). Cnut's mother was the daughter of the first duke of the Polans, Mieszko I; her name may have been Swietoslawa, but the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography article on Cnut (published 2004) states that her name is unknown. [PARAGRAPH:1]As a prince of Denmark, Cnut won the throne of England in 1016 in the wake of centuries of Viking activity in northwestern Europe. His accession to the Danish throne in 1018 brought the crowns of England and Denmark together. Cnut maintained his power by uniting Danes and Englishmen under cultural bonds of wealth and custom, rather than by sheer brutality. After a decade of conflict with opponents in Scandinavia, Cnut claimed the crown of Norway in Trondheim in 1028. The Swedish city Sigtuna was held by Cnut. He had coins struck there that called him king, but there is no narrative record of his occupation. [PARAGRAPH:1]The kingship of England lent the Danes an important link to the maritime zone between the islands of Great Britain and Ireland, where Cnut, like his father before him, had a strong interest and wielded much influence among the Gall-Ghaedhil, the Norse-Gaels, a people who dominated much of the Irish Sea region, including the Isle of Man, and western Scotland for a part of the Middle Ages; they were of Gaelic and North Germanic origin and as a whole exhibited a great deal of Gaelic and Norse cultural syncretism. [PARAGRAPH:1]Cnut's possession of England's dioceses and the continental Diocese of Denmark - with a claim laid upon it by the Holy Roman Empire's Archdiocese of Hamburg-Bremen - was a source of great leverage within the Church, gaining notable concessions from Pope Benedict VIII and his successor John XIX, such as one on the price of the pallium of his bishops. A pallium is an ecclesiastical vestment that was originally peculiar to the Pope, but for many centuries bestowed by him on metropolitans and primates as a symbol of the jurisdiction delegated to them by the Holy See. In that context it has remained connected to the papacy. At the time of this concession, Cnut was able provide his bishops with pallia equal in value and ostentation to those worn by the Pope himself, a not insignificant matter. During the coronation of the Holy Roman Emperor, Cnut also gained concessions on the tolls his people had to pay on the way to Rome from other magnates of medieval Christendom. After his 1026 victory against Norway and Sweden, and on his way to Rome for this coronation, Cnut, in a letter written for the benefit of his subjects, stated himself to be "king of all England and Denmark and the Norwegians and of some of the Swedes". Not an idle boast. At the time, he was more powerful and wealthier than the Holy Roman Emperor. [PARAGRAPH:2]Cnut ruled England for almost twenty years. The protection he lent against Viking raiders - many of them under his command - restored the prosperity that had been increasingly impaired since the resumption of Viking attacks in the 980s. The resources he commanded in England helped him to establish control of the majority of Scandinavia, too. [PARAGRAPH:1]In July 1017, to consolidate his power, Cnut wed Emma of Normandy, the widow of Æthelred and daughter of Richard the Fearless, the first Duke of Normandy. With Edmund dead, Cnut was quick to eliminate any prospective challenge from the survivors of the Wessex dynasty. The first year of his reign was marked by the executions of a number of English noblemen whom he considered suspect. Æthelred's son Eadwig fled from England but was killed on Cnut's orders. Edmund Ironside's sons Edward and Edmund likewise fled abroad, Edward eventually to Hungary. Emma's sons by Æthelred, Edward the Confessor and Alfred Atheling, went into exile among their relatives in Normandy. Cnut put forward Harthacnut, his son by Emma, to be his heir; Svein Knutsson and Harold Harefoot, his two sons from his marriage to Ælfgifu of Northampton, his handfast wife, were kept on the sidelines. [PARAGRAPH:1]In 1018, having collected a Danegeld amounting to the colossal sum of £72,000 levied nationwide, with an additional £10,500 extracted from London, Cnut paid off his army and sent most of them home. He retained 40 ships and their crews as a standing force in England. An annual tax called heregeld (army payment) was collected through the same system Æthelred had instituted in 1012 to reward Scandinavians in his service. [PARAGRAPH:1]Cnut extended the existing trend for multiple shires to be grouped together under a single ealdorman, dividing the country into four large administrative units whose geographical extent was based on the largest and most durable of the separate kingdoms that had preceded the unification of England. The officials responsible for these provinces were designated earls, a title of Scandinavian origin already in localised use in England, which now everywhere replaced that of ealdorman. Wessex was initially kept under Cnut's personal control, while Northumbria went to Erik of Hlathir, East Anglia to Thorkell the Tall, and Mercia remained in the hands of Eadric Streona. [PARAGRAPH:1]This initial distribution of power was short-lived. The chronically treacherous Eadric was executed within a year of Cnut's accession. Mercia passed to one of the leading families of the region, probably first to Leofwine, ealdorman of the Hwicce under Æthelred, but certainly soon to his son Leofric. In 1021 Thorkel the Tall also fell from favour and was outlawed. They served as junior Earls of Bernicia under the titular authority of the Earl of Northumbria. I inform you that I will be a gracious lord and a faithfull observer of God's rights and just secular law. (He exhorts his ealdormen to assist the bishops in the maintenance of) God's rights... and the benefit of the people.
